poem:
"Summer's Cultural Bounty"

Crowds amass near Eden's bounty;
Under the sun, a festival's hue.
Swift in song undulates the air,
Glyndebourne's chorus rises into crescendo,
Glastonbury's heartbeat lies within her hearers.
High art, high prices, an austerity dance.
Yet, the robin's song is more potent, 
and the peach in my hand rests --
a richer taste than any paid admission.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The Guardian view on culture: fight for the arts in our era of austerity | Editorial As summer arrives, so too does big culture. The Hay festival has just wound up, while later this month comes Glastonbury. Glyndebourne will have kicked into high gear just before the Edinburgh festival begins. All this, before mentioning the arrival on British shores of a thirtysomething singer-songwriter rarely referred to as Taylor Alison Swift. Big productions, big crowds, big prices: the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
